course.title: MICRO WORKSHOPS

course.class-restrictions: Must be in one of the following Classification(s):Graduate.
course.level-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):Graduate.

course.title: ECONOMETRICS WORKSHOPS
course.description: Seminars on advanced topics in macroeconomics, microeconomics, econometrics and applied microeconomic theory, presented through guest lectures by leading researchers.
course.class-restrictions: Must be in one of the following Classification(s):Graduate.
course.level-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):Graduate.

course.subject: ECON
course.title: GRADUATE RESEARCH
course.class-restrictions: Must be in one of the following Classification(s):Graduate.
course.level-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):Graduate.

course.subject: MECH
course.title: COMPUTATIONAL FLUID MECHANICS
course.description: Fundamental concepts of finite element methods in fluid mechanics, including spatial discretization and numerical integration in multidimensions, time-integration, and solution of nonlinear ordinary differential equation systems. Advanced numerical stabilization techniques designed for fluid mechanics problems. Strategies for solution of complex, real-world problems. Topics in large-scale computing, parallel processing, and visualization.

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: COMPUTATIONAL FLUID MECHANICS
course.description: Fundamental concepts of finite element methods in fluid mechanics, including spatial discretization and numerical integration in multidimensions, time-integration, and solution of nonlinear ordinary differential equation systems. Advanced numerical stabilization techniques designed for fluid mechanics problems. Strategies for solution of complex, real-world problems. Topics in large-scale computing, parallel processing, and visualization.

course.subject: CEVE
course.title: COMPUTATIONAL FLUID MECHANICS
course.description: Fundamental concepts of finite element methods in fluid mechanics, including spatial discretization and numerical integration in multi-dimensions, time-integration, and solution of nonlinear ordinary differential equation systems. Advanced numerical stabilization techniques designed for fluid mechanics problems. Strategies for solution of complex, real-world problems. Topics in large-scale computing, parallel processing, and visualization.

course.subject: MECH
course.title: COMPUTER AIDED DESIGN
course.description: Investigation of the integration of the computer into the area of design. Includes such subjects as optimization, finite element analysis, and commercial software.

course.subject: MECH
course.title: COMPUTATIONAL FLUID MECHANICS
course.description: Additional work required.

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: COMPUTATIONAL FLUID MECHANICS
course.description: Graduate version of BIOE 454. Additional work required.

course.subject: MECH
course.title: RESPIRATORY SYSTEM MECHANICS
course.description: Mechanics of ventilation, respiratory muscle mechanics, rib cage mechanics, mechanical coupling between the respiratory muscles and the rib cage, and inferences on mechanics from respiratory muscle anatomy. The class will meet in the Pulmonary Division at Baylor College of Medicine in the Texas Medical Center.

course.subject: MECH
course.title: MECH ENGINEERING PROBLEMS
course.description: An approved investigation or design project under the direction of a member of the staff. Open only to mechanical engineering majors.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Mechanical Engineering.

course.subject: MECH
course.title: MECH ENGINEERING PROBLEMS
course.description: An approved investigation or design project under the direction of a member of the staff. Open only to mechanical engineering majors.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Mechanical Engineering.

course.subject: MECH
course.title: INTRO TO AERODYNAMICS
course.description: Development of theories for the prediction of aerodynamic forces and moments acting on airfoils, wings, and bodies. Includes their design applications.

course.subject: MECH
course.title: MODELING TISSUE MECHANICS
course.description: Independent study and seminar course which focuses on modeling the mechanical properties of biological tissues. Data from experiments will be used to refine the predictions of nonlinear mathematical computer models. Aimed at juniors, seniors, and graduate students. Laboratory work performed at Baylor College of Medicine, computer work at Rice University.

course.subject: MECH
course.title: M.M.E. RESEARCH PROJECT I
course.description: This is the first part of the M.M.E. research project course. The faculty advisor, taking into account the background and research interests of the student as well as the research interests of the faculty advisor, will determine the contents. Course requirements will include a final report.

course.subject: MSCI
course.title: INTRO TO DESIGN
course.description: Introduction of fundamental aspects of design through semester-long group projects. Open to non-majors only with permission of instructor. Required for materials science and engineering majors.

course.subject: MSCI
course.title: MATERIALS SCIENCE
course.description: Introduction to the science of solid materials. Includes metals, ceramics, plastics, and semiconductors, as well as the properties of solid materials from atomic and macroscopic points of view. Required for mechanical engineering and materials science and engineering majors.

course.subject: MSCI
course.title: MECH PROPERTIES OF MATERIALS
course.description: Survey of the mechanical properties of solid materials. Includes basic mechanics, elasticity, plasticity, fracture, fatigue, creep, hardening mechanisms, mechanical testing, and structure-property relationships. Required for materials science and engineering majors.

course.subject: MSCI
course.title: PHYSICAL PROPERTIES OF SOLIDS
course.description: Survey of the electrical, magnetic, and optical properties of metals, semiconductors, and dielectrics based upon elementary band theory concepts. Required for materials science and engineering majors. Not offered every year.

course.subject: MSCI
course.title: MATERIALS SCIENCE SEMINAR
course.description: A series of seminars on selected topics in Materials Science. Required for materials science and engineering majors.

course.subject: MSCI
course.title: MATERIALS SCIENCE SEMINAR
course.description: See MSCI 500. Required for materials science and engineering majors.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: PRINCIPLES OF ARCHITECTURE III
course.description: What is the relationship between diagrammatic organization systems and the tectonic systems of construction? What is the relationship between the internal organization of a building's program and its immediate external context? The potentials of different structural systems in relationship to programmatic diagrams are foregrounded to develop an architectural proposal for a public program of medium size. Required for all architecture Majors.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: INTERMEDIATE PROBLEMS ARCH I
course.description: What is the relationship between the building and larger systems of the environment, constructed and natural, in which it sits and affects? This studio focuses on issues of architectures relationship to site and landscape environmental considerations and the relationship between systems and processes across the scales of architecture, urban and infrastructure. Required for all architecture Majors.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: HOUSTON ARCHITECTURE
course.description: This course consists of a series of illustrated lectures and walking tours that describe and analyze the architecture of Houston from the city's founding in 1836 to the present. Characteristic building types and exceptional works of architecture are identified; tours stimulate an awareness of the historical dimension of urban sites.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: CASE STU IN SUSTAINABLE DESIGN
course.description: This course will explore sustainable design from initial sustainable facility concepts and team organizations, to enlisting community support and process assessment. The course will develop into details about sustainable design, lessons learned, processes and outcomes. Space is limited and registration does not guarantee a space in this course. The final course roster is formulated on the first day class by the individual instructor.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: PHOTO FOR ARCHITECTS
course.description: Exploration of a variety of photographic techniques for architectural research, design, and presentation. Space is limited and registration does not guarantee a space in this course. The final course roster is formulated on the first day class by the individual instructor.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: ADVANCED TOPICS ARCHITECTURE
course.description: What is the agency of the architect as a public figure and the contributions of architecture to the emerging and existing public realms? This studio focuses on a very large building program or urban scaled design, engaging the complexity of the communities and shared spaces of the emerging metropolis/megalopolis. Required for all architecture Majors.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: SPECIAL PROJECTS
course.description: Independent research or design arranged in consultation with a faculty member. Subject to approval of faculty advisor and director.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: PRECEPTORSHIP PROGRAM
course.description: Full time internship for nine to twelve months under guidance of appointed preceptor. Required for all recipients of Rice B.A. degrees in pre-professional program of area majors who seek admission to graduate studies in Architecture.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: CORE DESIGN STUDIO I
course.description: The first in a sequence of four studios that foregrounds the relationship between form and program. By underscoring this pairing, the studio suggests that program and form amplify one another (rather than one superseding the other). The studio establishes a foundation in visual culture through examples in architecture and other design disciplines, art, and art history, as well as exercises in visual/spatial discrimination. The studio stresses the importance of iteration throughout the semester: individual projects emphasize a production/critique/refinement cycle, as does the overall sequence of projects that make up the entire studio.

course.subject: ARAB
course.title: INTRO TO MODERN ARABIC I
course.description: This course introduces students to Modern Standard and Colloquial Arabic within the cultural context of the Arab world. Students will learn speaking, listening, reading and writing skills through communicative drills and conversation practice. Multimedia material is an integral part of the course. Students will reach the Novice High Level.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: CORE DESIGN STUDIO III
course.description: The third in a sequence of four studios that foregrounds the relationship between form, program, and technology.

course.subject: ARAB
course.title: INTERMEDIATE MODERN ARABIC I
course.description: In this third course in the Arabic sequence, students will further their proficiency in speaking, listening, reading, and writing, utilizing complex sematic and syntactic structures. Multimedia material is an integral part of the course. Students will reach the Intermediate Low to Intermediate Mid proficiency.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: TECHNOLOGY I - THE FRAME
course.description: The course will introduce students to historical and contemporary structures through multi-media presentations, computer-based visualizations, field trips, and hands-on experiments with materials of construction and physical models of structures. This is an introductory interactive course on the art and science of designing engineered structures and is intended for freshmen and sophomores interested in both civil engineering and architecture. This course also addresses sustainability issues specific to structural systems including embodied energy, life cycle costs, and material re-use.

course.subject: CHIN
course.title: INTRODUCTORY CHINESE I
course.description: For students with no background in Chinese. Students will learn Pinyin and basic conversational skills. Students will learn to write approximately 200 Chinese characters. Students must also register for CHIN 131. The course and the co-requisite componenet will be graded jointly.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: ARCHITECTURAL PROBLEMS:STUDIO
course.description: Emphasis on abstract thought and design capabilities relevant to systematic processes of designing specific buildings and facilities. Note: there are three separate sections for this course.

course.subject: CHIN
course.title: INTRODUCTORY CHINESE I
course.description: For students with no background in Chinese. Students will learn Pinyin and basic conversational skills. Students will learn to write approximately 200 Chinese characters. Students must also register for CHIN 131. The course and the co-requisite componenet will be graded jointly.

course.subject: CHIN
course.title: ELEMENTARY CHINESE I
course.description: Continuation of CHIN 102. Emphasis on reading, writing, and speaking for personal needs. Students will be familiar with approximately 400 characters at the end of the course. Students must also register for CHIN 231. The course and co-requisite component will be graded jointly.

course.subject: CHIN
course.title: ELEMENTARY CHINESE I
course.description: Continuation of CHIN 102. Emphasis on reading, writing, and speaking for personal needs. Students will be familiar with approximately 400 characters at the end of the course. Students must also register for CHIN 231. The course and co-requisite component will be graded jointly.

course.subject: CHIN
course.title: INTERMEDIATE CHINESE I
course.description: Continuation of CHIN 202, for students whose home language is not Chinese. Oral skills cultivated through discussion after reading narrative texts and writing focused on techniques necessary for satisfying personal and social needs. Upon completion, students expected to be able to write approximately 650 characters and be able to perform communicative tasks appropriate to this range of characters.

course.subject: CHIN
course.title: ADVANCED CHINESE I
course.description: First advanced course, uses authentic materials (literary texts, films, Chinese media, and websites) to expose students to different discourse styles, help them cultivate sociocultural awareness and engage them in purposeful communicative tasks. Emphasis on essay writing, oral fluency (summarizing, comparing, narrating, describing...), and communicative competence. Classical Chinese is also introduced.

course.subject: FREN
course.title: ELEMENTARY FRENCH I
course.description: Introductory French. Concentration on all four language skills. Credit may not be received for both FREN 222 and FREN 101.

course.subject: FREN
course.title: ELEMENTARY FRENCH I
course.description: Introductory French. Concentration on all four language skills. Credit may not be received for both FREN 222 and FREN 101.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: ARCHITECTURAL PROBLEMS:STUDIO
course.description: Emphasis on abstract thought and design capabilities relevant to systematic processes of designing specific buildings and facilities. Note: there are three separate sections for this course.

course.subject: FREN
course.title: INTERMEDIATE FRENCH I
course.description: Communication based course. Focuses on the functional use of the language through linguistic, sociocultural and situational contexts. Develops all four language skills (listening, speaking, reading, writing). Credit may not be received for both FREN 225 and FREN 201.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: ARCHITECTURAL PROBLEMS:STUDIO
course.description: Emphasis on abstract thought and design capabilities relevant to systematic processes of designing specific buildings and facilities. Note: there are three separate sections for this course.

course.subject: FREN
course.title: INTERMEDIATE FRENCH II
course.description: Continuation of FREN 201. Credit may not be received for both FREN 226 and FREN 202.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: HIST, THEORY & STRUCTR: PARIS
course.description: Special seminars, lectures, and site visits relevant to history, urban theory, and structure of Paris and other European centers.

course.subject: FREN
course.title: ADV WRITTEN ORAL FRENCH
course.description: Aimed at developing competence in oral and written expression, with the special emphasis on stylistic variations, lexical nuances, and complex grammatical structures. Drawing on literary and journalistic sources, students will practice different styles of writing. Besides working on an individual project, students will create a collaborative story of their own invention.

course.subject: GERM
course.title: BEGINNING GERMAN I
course.description: Introductory-level development of proficiency and literacy in the language and cultures of German-speaking countries. Credit may not be received for both GERM 222 and GERM 101. No prior knowledge of German is required.

course.subject: GERM
course.title: BEGINNING GERMAN I
course.description: Introductory-level development of proficiency and literacy in the language and cultures of German-speaking countries. Credit may not be received for both GERM 222 and GERM 101. No prior knowledge of German is required.

course.subject: GERM
course.title: BEGINNING GERMAN I
course.description: Introductory-level development of proficiency and literacy in the language and cultures of German-speaking countries. Credit may not be received for both GERM 222 and GERM 101. No prior knowledge of German is required.

course.subject: GERM
course.title: INTERMEDIATE GERMAN I
course.description: Intermediate-level development of proficiency and literacy in the language and cultures of German-speaking countries.

course.subject: GERM
course.title: INTERMEDIATE GERMAN I
course.description: Intermediate-level development of proficiency and literacy in the language and cultures of German-speaking countries.

course.subject: HIND
course.title: HINDI TEACHING PRACTICUM
course.description: Students will work with instructor closely to acquire teaching skills in tutoring in Hindi.

course.subject: ITAL
course.title: ELEM ITALIAN I: LANG & CULTURE
course.description: ITAL 101 allows students to develop the abilities to communicate in Italian satisfactorily in everyday situations. Class meetings are primarily based on student interaction and students are expected to be active participants in the process. No prior knowledge of Italian is necessary. Must register for co-requisite ITAL 131.

course.subject: ITAL
course.title: ELEM ITALIAN I: LANG & CULTURE
course.description: ITAL 101 allows students to develop the abilities to communicate in Italian satisfactorily in everyday situations. Class meetings are primarily based on student interaction and students are expected to be active participants in the process. No prior knowledge of Italian is necessary. Must register for co-requisite ITAL 131.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: ARCHITECTURAL PROBLEMS
course.description: Advanced issues in building design and urban infrastructure using Paris as context. Exploration of compound design processes resulting in the development of complex building typologies.

course.subject: JAPA
course.title: INTRODUCTION TO JAPANESE I
course.description: This course emphasizes the learning of basic grammatical structures and vocabulary of modern Japanese to develop oral competence at the novice level. This goal is achieved primarily through aural-oral activities and task-oriented instruction for students to be able to handle uncomplicated communicative tasks.

course.subject: JAPA
course.title: INTERMEDIATE JAPANESE I
course.description: Further practice in conversation, grammar, reading and composition. Class will be conducted exclusively in Japanese. Students will be able to accomplish a variety of uncomplicated communicative tasks. More emphasis on kanji practice with the Japanese writing system.

course.subject: KORE
course.title: INTRODUCTION TO KOREAN I
course.description: Introduction to Korean language and culture. Acquisition of the fundamentals of the four language skills. No prior knowledge of Korean is required.

course.subject: KORE
course.title: INTERMEDIATE KOREAN I
course.description: Continuation of the development of speaking, listening, reading, and writing skills.

course.subject: KORE
course.title: KOREAN TEACHING PRACTICUM
course.description: Under the instructor's close supervision, students with a high level of proficiency in Korean acquire teaching skills by tutoring the students in lower level.

course.subject: PORT
course.title: INTRODUCTION TO PORTUGUESE I
course.description: Introduction to the study of the Portuguese language and culture with emphasis on the development of the listening, speaking, reading and writing. This course uses textbooks as well as music, websites and videos for access to various kinds of cultural material and pretexts for communication.

course.subject: PORT
course.title: INTERMEDIATE PORTUGUESE I
course.description: Students progress to more creative oral and written communicative activities. Texts, music, videos, and the internet will be used to address a wide variety of topics and real-life situations.

course.subject: RUSS
course.title: INTRODUCTION TO RUSSIAN I
course.description: An introduction to the fundamentals of Russian grammar and basic conversation topics. Includes pronunciation, reading, oral, aural, and translation practice. Also includes a basic introduction to Russian culture. No prior knowledge of Russian is required.

course.subject: RUSS
course.title: INTERMEDIATE RUSSIAN I
course.description: A continuation of the fundamentals of Russian grammar and conversation topics. Includes oral, aural, composition, translation, and reading practice. Attention is also given to Russian cultural topics and current events.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: PHOTO FOR ARCHITECTS
course.description: Exploration of a variety of photographic techniques for architectural research, design, and presentation. Space is limited and registration does not guarantee a space in this course. The final course roster is formulated on the first day class by the individual instructor.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: INTRO SPANISH LANG & CULTURE I
course.description: Students develop ability to communicate in Spanish satisfactory in everyday situations. Classes primarily based on student interaction and students are expected to be active particpants in process. No prior knowledge of Spanish is necessary. Students must choose co-requisite SPAN 131 to complete registration. No credit for both SPAN 222 and 101.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: INTRO SPANISH LANG & CULTURE I
course.description: Students develop ability to communicate in Spanish satisfactory in everyday situations. Classes primarily based on student interaction and students are expected to be active particpants in process. No prior knowledge of Spanish is necessary. Students must choose co-requisite SPAN 131 to complete registration. No credit for both SPAN 222 and 101.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: INTRO SPANISH LANG & CULTURE I
course.description: Students develop ability to communicate in Spanish satisfactory in everyday situations. Classes primarily based on student interaction and students are expected to be active particpants in process. No prior knowledge of Spanish is necessary. Students must choose co-requisite SPAN 131 to complete registration. No credit for both SPAN 222 and 101.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: INTRO SPAN LANG & CULTURE II
course.description: Continuation of SPAN 101. Students develop the ability to communicate satisfactorily in everday situations. Classes based on student interaction and students are active participants in this process. Students must choose any co-requisite class SPAN 132 on Tues/Thurs to complete registration. Cannot receive credit for both SPAN 223 and SPAN 102.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: INTRO SPAN LANG & CULTURE II
course.description: Continuation of SPAN 101. Students develop the ability to communicate satisfactorily in everday situations. Classes based on student interaction and students are active participants in this process. Students must choose any co-requisite class SPAN 132 on Tues/Thurs to complete registration. Cannot receive credit for both SPAN 223 and SPAN 102.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: INTERMEDIATE SPANISH I
course.description: Intermediate level students increase Spanish proficiency and cultural awareness through learner-centered communicative activities and thoughful processing of authentic materials. Students must also register for SPAN 231. This course and its co-requisite component are graded jointly. Credit may not be received for both SPAN 225 and SPAN 201.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: INTERMEDIATE SPANISH I
course.description: Intermediate level students increase Spanish proficiency and cultural awareness through learner-centered communicative activities and thoughful processing of authentic materials. Students must also register for SPAN 231. This course and its co-requisite component are graded jointly. Credit may not be received for both SPAN 225 and SPAN 201.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: INTERMEDIATE SPANISH I
course.description: Intermediate level students increase Spanish proficiency and cultural awareness through learner-centered communicative activities and thoughful processing of authentic materials. Students must also register for SPAN 231. This course and its co-requisite component are graded jointly. Credit may not be received for both SPAN 225 and SPAN 201.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: INTERMEDIATE SPANISH I
course.description: Intermediate level students increase Spanish proficiency and cultural awareness through learner-centered communicative activities and thoughful processing of authentic materials. Students must also register for SPAN 231. This course and its co-requisite component are graded jointly. Credit may not be received for both SPAN 225 and SPAN 201.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: INTERMEDIATE SPANISH II
course.description: This is a continuation of SPAN 201. Classes incorporate proficiency based instruction focused on expanding vocabulary and further developing cultural awareness and communicative skills. Students must register for SPAN 232. This course and its co-requisite component will be graded jointly. Credit may not be received for both SPAN 226 and SPAN 202.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: INTERMEDIATE SPANISH II
course.description: This is a continuation of SPAN 201. Classes incorporate proficiency based instruction focused on expanding vocabulary and further developing cultural awareness and communicative skills. Students must register for SPAN 232. This course and its co-requisite component will be graded jointly. Credit may not be received for both SPAN 226 and SPAN 202.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: ADVANCED SPANISH I
course.description: This course aims to bring students from an intermediate towards an advanced level of proficiency in Spanish. Students will develop fluency and communicative competence through exposure to literary texts, newspaper and web articles, films and videos, in their cultural context. Emphasis will be on conversation strategies, vocabulary expansion and the writing of essays.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: ADVANCED SPANISH I
course.description: This course aims to bring students from an intermediate towards an advanced level of proficiency in Spanish. Students will develop fluency and communicative competence through exposure to literary texts, newspaper and web articles, films and videos, in their cultural context. Emphasis will be on conversation strategies, vocabulary expansion and the writing of essays.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: ADVANCED SPANISH I
course.description: This course aims to bring students from an intermediate towards an advanced level of proficiency in Spanish. Students will develop fluency and communicative competence through exposure to literary texts, newspaper and web articles, films and videos, in their cultural context. Emphasis will be on conversation strategies, vocabulary expansion and the writing of essays.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: ADVANCED SPANISH I
course.description: This course aims to bring students from an intermediate towards an advanced level of proficiency in Spanish. Students will develop fluency and communicative competence through exposure to literary texts, newspaper and web articles, films and videos, in their cultural context. Emphasis will be on conversation strategies, vocabulary expansion and the writing of essays.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: ADVANCED SPANISH II
course.description: This course aims to bring students from an intermediate towards an advanced level of proficiency in Spanish. Students will develop fluency and communicative competence through exposure to literary texts, newspaper and web articles, films and videos, in their cultural context. Emphasis will be on conversation strategies, vocabulary expansion and the writing of essays.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: ADV SPAN BI-CULTURAL STUDENTS
course.description: SPAN 303 aims to bring students to advanced proficiency in Spanish, enabling them to interact confidently in a wide variety of contexts, while providing them with cultural insights about the Hispanic world. It is designed for students who come with bi-cultural exposure and at least intermediate proficiency in Spanish.

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: COMMERCIAL SPANISH I
course.description: This course will familiarize students with the world of business in Spanish through activities dealing with current socio-economic events in Latin America and Spain, commercial correspondence, cross cultural awareness and presentations. Supranational organizations in the area will be topic of a final project for the class.
course.pre-requisites: SPAN 301OR SPAN 302OR SPAN 303OR SPAN 304OR SPAN 306OR SPAN 307OR SPAN 308OR SPAN 313OR SPAN 314OR SPAN 315OR SPAN 316

course.subject: SPAN
course.title: SCIENTIFIC SPANISH I
course.description: Content-based course in Spanish in which the student will be familiarized with uses of the language necessary to deal with scientific issues in the Spanish-speaking world. Science background is not required since we mainly work with popular science topics.
course.pre-requisites: SPAN 301OR SPAN 302OR SPAN 303OR SPAN 304OR SPAN 305OR SPAN 306OR SPAN 307OR SPAN 308OR SPAN 314OR SPAN 315OR SPAN 316

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: SPECIAL PROJECTS
course.description: Independent research or design arranged in consultation with a faculty member subject to approval of the student's faculty advisor and director.

course.subject: ARCH
course.title: SPECIAL PROJECTS
course.description: Independent research or design arranged in consultation with a faculty member subject to approval of the student's faculty advisor and director.

course.subject: ENGL
course.title: PEDAGOGY
course.description: Continuation of ENGL 510.

course.subject: ENGL
course.title: CRITICAL READING AND WRITING
course.description: A course designed for and required of all prospective English majors. Emphasis is on close reading, literary interpretation, and critical writing. Attention is paid to the major genres (poetry, drama, and fiction) across a range of historical periods.

course.subject: ENGL
course.title: CRITICAL READING AND WRITING
course.description: A course designed for and required of all prospective English majors. Emphasis is on close reading, literary interpretation, and critical writing. Attention is paid to the major genres (poetry, drama, and fiction) across a range of historical periods.

course.subject: ENGL
course.title: PRACTICES OF LITERARY STUDY
course.description: A course that identifies and explores key concepts of recent critical writing. Students read short texts of contemporary theory and discuss the relation between theory and literature. Required for English majors.

course.subject: COMP
course.title: COMPILER CONSTRUCTION
course.description: Topics in the design of programming language translators, including parsing, run-time storage management, error recovery, code generation and optimization.

course.subject: COMP
course.title: COMPUTER SYSTEMS ARCHITECTURE
course.description: Evolution of key architecture concepts found in advanced uniprocessor systems. Fundamental and advanced pipelining techniques and associated issues for improving processor performance. Illustrated with RISC processors such as the ARM processor. Examine several metrics for processor performance, such as Amdahls law. Key concepts of data and program memory systems found in modern systems with memory hierarchies and caches. Perform experiments in cache performance analysis. Influence of technology trends, such as Moores law, on processor implementation. Approaches for exploiting instruction level parallelism, such as VLIW. Introduction to parallel and multicore architectures. Introduction to processor architectures targeted for embedded applications.

course.subject: ENGL
course.title: PRACTICES OF LITERARY STUDY
course.description: A course that identifies and explores key concepts of recent critical writing. Students read short texts of contemporary theory and discuss the relation between theory and literature. Required for English majors.

course.subject: COMP
course.title: ALGORITHMIC ROBOTICS
course.description: Robots have fascinated people for generations. Today, robots are built for applications as diverse as exploring remote planets, de-mining war zones, cleaning toxic waste, assembling cars, inspecting pipes in industrial plants and mowing lawns. Robots are also interacting with humans in a variety of ways: robots are museum guides, robots pets entertain, and robots assist surgeon sin life threatening operations. The field of robotics studies not only the design of new mechanisms but also the development of algorithms, and frameworks to make these mechanism useful in the physical world, integrating science, engineering, mathematics and more recently biology and sociology, in a unique way. This class will present fundamental algorithmic advances that enable todays robots to move in real environments and plan their actions. The class involves a significant programming project.

course.subject: COMP
course.title: COMPUTER SCIENCE PROJECTS
course.description: Theoretical and experimental investigation under staff direction.

course.subject: COMP
course.title: COMPUTER SCIENCE TEACHING
course.description: A combination of in-service teaching and a seminar.

course.subject: ENGL
course.title: TOPICS IN LITERARY THEORY
course.description: An introduction, for first-semester graduate students, to theoretical issues, problems, and approaches current in the profession of literary study.

course.subject: THEA
course.title: STAGE CRAFT
course.description: Introduction to materials, tools, and standard theatre production techniques. Theory and practice of scenic building and painting techniques, creation of props, sound support requirements, and running crew during performance. No Lab hours required.

course.subject: THEA
course.title: THEA TECH: COSTUME CONSTRUCTON
course.description: Introduction to the materials, tools, and standard techniques of costume/clothing construction. Lab hours required.

course.subject: THEA
course.title: ACTING I
course.description: Introduction to the fundamentals of acting through the exploration of actor training techniques based on the theories of Stanislavsky, Strasburg, Adler, Meisner, and Hagen, emphasizing the actor's primary tools: voice, body, emotional life, and imagination.

course.subject: COMP
course.title: MOBILE AND WIRELESS NETWORKING
course.description: Study of network protocols for mobile and wireless networking, particularly at the media access control, network, and transport protocol layers. Focus is on the unique problems and challenges presented by the properties of wireless transmission and host or router mobility.

course.subject: COMP
course.title: COMPUTER SCIENCE PROJECTS
course.description: Advanced theoretical and experimental investigations under staff direction.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: SINGLE VARIABLE CALCULUS I
course.description: Differentiation, extrema, Newton's method, integration, fundamental theorem of calculus, area, volume, natural logarithm, exponential, arc length, surface area, Simpson's rule, L'Hopital's rule. May substitute MATH 111-112 or take MATH 101 after completing MATH 111.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: SINGLE VARIABLE CALCULUS I
course.description: Differentiation, extrema, Newton's method, integration, fundamental theorem of calculus, area, volume, natural logarithm, exponential, arc length, surface area, Simpson's rule, L'Hopital's rule. May substitute MATH 111-112 or take MATH 101 after completing MATH 111.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: SINGLE VARIABLE CALCULUS II
course.description: Continuation of MATH 101. Includes further techniques of integration, as well as infinite sequences and series, tests for convergence, power series, radius of convergence, polar coordinates, parametric equations, and arc length.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: SINGLE VARIABLE CALCULUS II
course.description: Continuation of MATH 101. Includes further techniques of integration, as well as infinite sequences and series, tests for convergence, power series, radius of convergence, polar coordinates, parametric equations, and arc length.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: SINGLE VARIABLE CALCULUS II
course.description: Continuation of MATH 101. Includes further techniques of integration, as well as infinite sequences and series, tests for convergence, power series, radius of convergence, polar coordinates, parametric equations, and arc length.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: FUND THEOREM OF CALCULUS
course.description: Study of calculus, forming with MATH 112 a slower-paced version of MATH 101/102. Contains less detail in the coverage of infinite series. Students may take MATH 111/112 followed by MATH 102, or MATH 111 followed by MATH 101/102.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: ORD DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
course.description: Study of ordinary differential equations (e.g., solutions to separable and linear first-order equations and to higher-order linear equations with constant coefficients, the properties of solutions to differential equations, and numerical solution methods) and linear algebra (e.g., vector spaces and solutions to algebraic linear equations, dimension, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors of a matrix), as well as the application of linear algebra to first-order systems of differential equations and the qualitative theory of nonlinear systems and phase portraits. Use of the computers in Owlnet as part of each homework assignment required.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: ORD DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
course.description: Study of ordinary differential equations (e.g., solutions to separable and linear first-order equations and to higher-order linear equations with constant coefficients, the properties of solutions to differential equations, and numerical solution methods) and linear algebra (e.g., vector spaces and solutions to algebraic linear equations, dimension, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors of a matrix), as well as the application of linear algebra to first-order systems of differential equations and the qualitative theory of nonlinear systems and phase portraits. Use of the computers in Owlnet as part of each homework assignment required.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: ORD DIFFERENTIAL EQUATIONS
course.description: Study of ordinary differential equations (e.g., solutions to separable and linear first-order equations and to higher-order linear equations with constant coefficients, the properties of solutions to differential equations, and numerical solution methods) and linear algebra (e.g., vector spaces and solutions to algebraic linear equations, dimension, eigenvalues, and eigenvectors of a matrix), as well as the application of linear algebra to first-order systems of differential equations and the qualitative theory of nonlinear systems and phase portraits. Use of the computers in Owlnet as part of each homework assignment required.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: MULTIVARIABLE CALCULUS
course.description: Study of gradient, divergence, and curl, Lagrange multipliers, multiple integrals, as well as line integrals, conservative vector fields, Green's theorem, Stokes's theorem, and Gauss's theorem. May substitute Math 221 and 222.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: HONORS CALCULUS III
course.description: This course and MATH 222 include the material of MATH 212 and much more. Topology of Rn, calculus for functions of several variables, linear and multilinear algebra, theory of determinants, inner product spaces, integration on manifolds.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: INTRODUCTION TO ANALYSIS I
course.description: A thorough treatment of basic methods of analysis such as metric spaces, compactness, sequences and series of functions. Also further topics in analysis, such as Hilbert spaces, Fourier series, Sturm- Liouville theory.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: LINEAR ALGEBRA
course.description: Linear transformations and matrices, solution of linear equations, inner products eigenvalues and eigenvectors, the spectral theorem for real symmetric matrices, applications of Jordan canonical form. Credit may not be received for both MATH 354 and MATH 355.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: INTRO PARTIAL DIFF EQUATIONS
course.description: Laplace transform: inverse transform, applications to constant coefficient differential equations. Boundary value problems: Fourier series, Bessel functions, Legendre polynomials.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: DIFFERENTIAL GEOMETRY
course.description: Study of the differential geometry of curves and surfaces in R3. Includes an introduction to the concept of curvature and thorough treatment of the Gauss-Bonnet theorem.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: PARTIAL DIFFERENTIAL EQNS I
course.description: First order of partial differential equations. The method of characteristics. Analysis of the solutions of the wave equation, heat equation and Laplace's equation. Integral relations and Green's functions. Potential theory, Dirichlet and Neumann problems. Asymptotic methods: the method of stationary phase, geometrical optics, regular and singular perturbation methods.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: INTEGRATION THEORY
course.description: Lebesgue theory of measure and integration.

course.subject: ENGL
course.title: LITERATURE & THE ENVIRONMENT
course.description: A course that asks the questions: How does literature express or shape environmental values? In this class we will read American fiction and nonfiction exploring the relationship between human and nonhuman nature.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: TOPICS IN COMPLEX ANALYSIS
course.description: Special topics include Riemann mapping theorem, Runge's Theorem, elliptic function theory, prime number theorem, Riemann surfaces, et al.

course.subject: ENGL
course.title: ART AND LITERATURE
course.description: An exploration of how artworks in various media become meaningful at the level of detail. This work will entail learning how to look, think, and feel at the same time. Key authors and artists may include Vermeer(painting), Hitchcock(film), Hammett(detective fiction).

course.subject: MATH
course.title: GEOMETRIC TOPOLOGY
course.description: Introduction to algebraic methods in topology and differential topology. Elementary homotopy theory. Covering spaces.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: ABSTRACT ALGEBRA II
course.description: Ring theory: ideals, polynomials, factorization. Advanced linear algebra: quadratic forms, canonical forms. Field theory: extensions, Galois theory, soluability in radicals. Continuation of MATH 356.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: CURRENT MATHEMATICS SEMINAR
course.description: Lectures on topics of recent research in mathematics delivered by mathematics graduate students and faculty.
course.instructor: Orcan Ekmekci, Betul; Tweedy, Eamonn P.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: GRADUATE TEACHING SEMINAR
course.description: Discussion on teaching issues and practice lectures by participants as preparation for classroom teaching of mathematics.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: MATHEMATICAL SCIENCES
course.instructor: Cochran, Tim D.; Harvey, Shelly L.

course.subject: MATH
course.title: HONORS LINEAR ALGEBRA
course.description: Vector spaces, linear transformations and matrices, theory of systems of linear equations, determinants, eigenvalues and diagonalizability, inner product spaces; and optional material chosen from: dual vector spaces, spectral theorem for self-adjoint operators, Jordan canonical form. Content is similar to that of MATH 355, but with more emphasis on theory. The course will include instruction on how to construct mathematical proofs. This course is appropriate for potential Mathematics majors and others interested in learning how to construct rigorous mathematical arguments. Credit may not be received for both MATH 354 and MATH 355.

course.subject: ANTH
course.title: INTRO TO STUDY OF LANGUAGE
course.description: Overview of the scientific study of the structure and function of language. Introduces the main fields of linguistics: phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, discourse, historical linguistics, sociolinguistics, and psycholinguistics. Highlights the interdisciplinary relationship of linguistics with anthropology, sociology, psychology, and cognitive sciences.

course.subject: LING
course.title: INTRO TO STUDY OF LANGUAGE
course.description: Overview of the scientific study of the structure and function of language. Introduces the main fields of linguistics: phonetics, phonology, morphology, syntax, semantics, discourse, historical linguistics, sociolinguistics, and psycholinguistics. Highlights the interdisciplinary relationship of linguistics with anthropology, sociology, psychology, and cognitive sciences.

course.subject: ANTH
course.title: PHONETICS
course.description: Introductory study of sound as it relates to speech and sound systems in the world's languages. Speech sounds are examined in terms of production mechanisms (articulatory phonetics), propagation mechanisms (acoustic phonetics), and perception mechanisms (auditory phonetics). Includes a basic introduction to Digital Signal Processing.

course.subject: LING
course.title: PHONETICS
course.description: Introductory study of sound as it relates to speech and sound systems in the world's languages. Speech sounds are examined in terms of production mechanisms (articulatory phonetics), propagation mechanisms (acoustic phonetics), and perception mechanisms (auditory phonetics). Includes a basic introduction to Digital Signal Processing.

course.subject: ARTS
course.title: THE PROVINCE OF ART
course.description: Explores exhibition practicdes at play in Houston's contemporary art scene, considering the various methods and strategies employed by area museums, galleries and public collections. Examines the shifting relationship between artist, institution, curator, and critic-writer, paying a particular attention to the role of the curator as a mediator of art.

course.subject: ANTH
course.title: INDEPENDENT STUDY
course.description: Directed reading and preparation of written papers on anthropological subjects not offered in the curriculum and advanced study of subjects on which courses are offered.

course.subject: ENGL
course.title: INTRODUCTION TO THEATRE
course.description: A survey course of the art and theory of the theatre through an examination of dramatic literature from the Greeks through the modern era. The course will also explore the craft of the theatre as it is practiced today. Requires attending several theatre productions in local Houston venues.

course.subject: ANTH
course.title: DIRECTED HONORS RESEARCH
course.description: A two-semester sequence of independent research culminating in the preparation and defense of an honors thesis. Open only to candidates formally accepted into the honors program.

course.subject: ANTH
course.title: LINGUISTIC ANALYSIS
course.description: A hands-on, data-oriented approach to how different languages construct words and sentences. Students will develop skills in linguistic problem solving and the foundations for pursuing grammatical description. Topics: word classes, morphology, tense-aspect-modality, clause structure, word order, grammatical relations, existentials/possessives/locatives, voice/valence, questions, negation, relative clauses, complements, causatives.

course.subject: ASIA
course.title: INTRO TO ASIAN CIVILIZATIONS
course.description: A team-taught interdisciplinary course focusing on certain major philosophical, religious and artistic traditions of pre-modern Asia, with an emphasis on the historical processes by which ideas, people, products, technologies and skills circulated within and beyond state boundaries.
course.instructor: Smith, Richard J.; Balabanlilar, Lisa A.; Huang, Shih-Shan S.

course.subject: ASIA
course.title: INDEPENDENT STUDY
course.description: Reading or research project to be determined by discussions between student(s) and faculty member(s).

course.subject: SOCI
course.title: INDEPENDENT STUDY
course.description: Directed reading and written papers on subjects not regularly offered; advanced study of subjects on which courses are offered.

course.subject: SOCI
course.title: ETHNOGRAPHIC RESEARCH
course.description: Beginning with the theoretical frameworks for ethnographic and other qualitative research methods, the course will cover ethics, entry, observation, field notes, interviewing, data analysis, and writing reports. It will offer a hands-on approach combining lectures, research through lectures, readings, and fieldwork. Field projects can be conducted in group, classroom, campus, or community settings.

course.subject: NAVA
course.title: NAVAL ORIENTATION
course.description: An introduction to naval traditions and customs, seamanship, naval organization and missions, and the fundamental concepts of sea power.

course.subject: NAVA
course.title: NAVAL ENGINEERING
course.description: Ship propulsion systems, auxiliary systems, steering systems, electrical power distribution, ship design, ship stability and damage control measures.

course.subject: NAVA
course.title: NAVAL OPERATIONS & SEAMANSHIP
course.description: An analysis of ship movements, formations, and fleet operations; includes Rules of the Road, maneuvering board, tactical publications and communications.

course.subject: NAVA
course.title: LEADERSHIP MANAGEMENT I
course.description: An introduction to the principles and concepts of management, organization, leadership, information systems, and decision making.

course.subject: HIST
course.title: MODERN EUROPE, 1450-1789
course.description: Course provides an introduction to European history from 1500 to the French Revolution, tracing Europe's rise to world dominance via capitalism, the nation-state, science and technology, and a secular world view. It asks how conditions in the rest of the world allowed European imperialism and colonialism to triumph.

course.subject: HIST
course.title: INTRO TO ASIAN CIVILIZATIONS
course.description: A team-taught interdisciplinary course focusing on certain major philosophical, religious and artistic traditions of pre-modern Asia, with an emphasis on the historical processes by which ideas, people, products, technologies and skills circulated within and beyond state boundaries.
course.instructor: Smith, Richard J.; Balabanlilar, Lisa A.; Huang, Shih-Shan S.

course.subject: HIST
course.title: INDEPENDENT STUDY
course.description: Independent study under the supervision of a history faculty member. Hours are variable. Department Chair's permission required.

course.subject: HIST
course.title: ADVANCED RESEARCH SEMINAR
course.description: Restricted to students admitted to History Honors Program. Seminar is designed to advance students from preliminary research to development of a formal prospectus for the honors thesis and a first draft of one section.

course.subject: HIST
course.title: INTRO DOCTORAL STUDIES
course.description: Introduction to a range of methodological and theoretical approaches to historical research, as well as to important current debates about the nature of historical investigation and interpretation.

course.subject: HIST
course.title: GRADUATE READING
course.description: Graduate reading in conjunction with another course.

course.subject: HIST
course.title: DIRECTED READINGS
course.description: Graduate level independent readings course. Topics vary.

course.subject: ASTR
course.title: STARS GALAXIES & THE UNIVERSE
course.description: An introductory course for students in academic programs. The formation, evolution, and death of stars; the composition and evolution of galaxies; the structure and evolution of the universe.

course.subject: ASTR
course.title: INTRO ASTROPHYSICS-STARS
course.description: Introduction to celestial mechanics, radiative transfer, stellar structure, and stellar remnants (including black holes and neutron stars). Aspects of stellar atmospheres may also be explored. Together, ASTR 350 and ASTR 360 provide a comprehensive survey of modern astrophysics needed for senior research and graduate study in astronomy. Either ASTR 350 or 360 may be taken first.

course.subject: ASTR
course.title: UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH SEMINAR
course.description: Seminar on current research topics in astronomy, astrophysics, and space physics for juniors and seniors. Students will be expected to give one oral presentation each semester.

course.subject: ASTR
course.title: GRADUATE RESEARCH SEMINAR
course.description: A presentation of current research programs in the department.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: MECHANICS (WITH LAB)
course.description: Calculus-based survey of physics. Includes classes and lab exercises on topics chosen from mechanics, electricity, and magnetism. Primarily for physical science and engineering students. May receive credit for only one of PHYS 101, 111, 125, AP Physics-B (PHYS 141), and AP Physics-C, MECH (PHYS 101)
course.instructor: Dunning, F B.; Corcoran, Marjorie D.; Niestemski, Liang R.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: MECHANICS (WITH LAB)
course.description: Calculus-based survey of physics. Includes classes and lab exercises on topics chosen from mechanics, electricity, and magnetism. Primarily for physical science and engineering students with strong high school backgrounds in physics. May receive credit for only one of PHYS 101, 111, 125, AP Physics-B (PHYS 141), and AP Physics-C, MECH (PHYS 101).

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: GENERAL PHYSICS (WITH LAB)
course.description: Calculus-based survey of physics. Includes classes and lab exercises on topics chosen from mechanics, waves, electricity, magnetism, optics, and modern physics. Primarily for bioscience and premedical students. May receive credit for only one of PHYS 101, 111, 125, AP Physics-B (PHYS 141), and AP Physics-C, MECH (PHYS 101).

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: WAVES AND OPTICS
course.description: Fundamentals of oscillations and waves and properties of electromagnetic waves. Basic principles of geometric optics, interference and diffraction, including Fourier methods.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: ELEMENTARY PHYSICS LAB
course.description: Laboratory on waves and optics.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: INTERMEDIATE MECHANICS
course.description: Classical mechanics and appropriate mathematical methods. Emphasis on problem solving.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: INTRO TO QUANTUM PHYSICS I
course.description: Fundamentals of quantum mechanics and applications to atomic and molecular structure.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: JUNIOR PHYSICS LAB I
course.description: Lab exercises in electronics, noise reduction, statistics and particle counting.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: JUNIOR PHYSICS LAB II
course.description: Lab exercises illustrating topics in the upper-division physics curriculum.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: INTRO NUCLEAR&PARTIC PHYSICS
course.description: Survey of history and current state of nuclear and particle physics. The emphasis is on experimental results and how they led to our current understanding of the strong and electroweak interactions. Some recent advances are discussed in detail.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: STATISTICAL & THERMAL PHYSICS
course.description: Includes classical thermodynamics; classical & quantum statistical mechanics; Fermi, Bose, and classical gases; magnetic systems; and phase equilibria.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: INDEPENDENT RESEARCH
course.description: A reading course in special topics.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: INTRODUCTION TO PLASMA PHYSICS
course.description: Fundamental processes in cosmic and laboratory plasmas: gas dynamics, kinetic theory, magnetohydrodynamics, wave and shocks, individual particle drifts, collisions and electrical conductivities, geometric and distribution instabilities.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH
course.description: Research projects conducted under supervision of departmentally approved faculty. Open to juniors and seniors majoring in physics and astronomy. May be repeated for credit. PHYS 493/494 must be taken concurrently with PHYS 491/492 when used in partial fulfillment of B.S. degree requirements.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Astronomy,Astrophysics,Chemical Physics,Physics.
course.class-restrictions: Must be in one of the following Classification(s):Junior,Senior.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: UNDERGRADUATE RESEARCH SEMINAR
course.description: Weekly seminar for juniors and seniors in which presentations on research topics and/or topics in the scientific literature will be given. Open to juniors and seniors majoring in physics and astronomy.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Astronomy,Astrophysics,Chemical Physics,Physics.
course.class-restrictions: Must be in one of the following Classification(s):Junior,Senior.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: CLASSICAL DYNAMICS
course.description: Lagrangian and Hamiltonian mechanics.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: QUANTUM MECHANICS I
course.description: Graduate level course on non-relativistic quantum mechanics. Topics include early quantum theory, one-dimensional systems, matrix formulation, quantum dynamics, symmetries and conservation laws, bound states, scattering, spin, and identical particles, perturbation theory.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: NANOSTRUCTURE/NANOTECHNOLOG
course.description: Physics of structures and devices at the nanometer scale. After a review of solid state physics, topics include nanostructured materials, nanoelectronics, and nanomagnetism. Emphasis on relevance of nanophysics to current and future technologies.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: INTRO NUCLEAR&PARTIC PHYSICS
course.description: Survey of history and current state of nuclear and particle physics with the emphasis on experimental results and how they led to our current understanding of the strong and electroweak interactions. Some recent advances are discussed in detail. Requires completion of a Monte Carlo simulation project.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: INTRO TO SOLID STATE PHYSICS I
course.description: Fundamental concepts of crystalline solids, including crystal structure, band theory of electrons, and lattice vibration theory.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: SURFACE PHYSICS
course.description: An introduction to surface- and low-dimensional physics covering experimental surface physics and ultra-high vacuum technology, crystal structure, chemical analysis, epitaxy, nanoscale electronic and magnetic structures and devices, elementary excitations, optical properties and nanoscale sensitive magnetic and non-magnetic spectroscopies.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: ELECTRODYNAMICS & NANOPHOTONIC
course.description: This course covers computational and numerical methods for calculating electromagnetic fields and propagation in complex geometries on the nano and microscale. Methods include the finite difference time domain method, boundary element methods, Greens functions methods, finite element methods, the discrete dipole approximation and relaxation methods.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: TEACHING PRACTICUM
course.description: Supervised teaching for graduate students.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: TEACHING PRACTICUM
course.description: Supervised teaching for graduate students.

course.subject: PHYS
course.title: GRADUATE RESEARCH
course.description: Thesis research under the supervision of department faculty.

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: BIOENGINEERING FUNDAMENTALS
course.description: Introduction to material, energy, charge, and momentum balances in biological systems. Steady state and transient conservation equations for mass, energy, charge and momentum will be derived and applied using basic mathematical principles, physical laws, stoichiometry, and thermodynamic properties. Problem based learning groups will solve open-ended problems. Required for students intending to major in bioengineering.
course.pre-requisites: MATH 101AND MATH 102AND CHEM 122AND CAAM 210AND (PHYS 101OR PHYS 125OR PHYS 111)AND (PHYS 102OR PHYS 126OR PHYS 112)

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: CELLULAR ENGINEERING
course.description: Introduction to engineering principles and modeling regulation and circuitry at the cellular level. Topics include genetic metabolic networks and cell surface interactions.

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: BIOMED ENGINR INSTRUMENTATION
course.description: This is an introductory level course on fundamentals of biomedical engineering instrumentation and analysis. Topics include measurement principles; fundamental concepts in electronics including circuit analysis, data acquisition, amplifiers, filters and A/D converters; Fourier analysis; temperature, pressure, and flow measurements in biological systems.

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: ENGINEERING UG RESEARCH
course.description: Independent investigation of a specific topic or problem in modern bioengineering research under the direction of a selected faculty member. Research project has a strong engineering component.

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: BIOPROCESSING LAB MODULE
course.description: Students design and conduct a series of experiments to observe the growth of E. coli under different conditions, including agar plates, shake flasks, and a small-scale bioreactor. The E. coli has been transformed with a plasmid that produces beta-galactosidase. Engineering applications are emphasized. Some work "off hours" (early evening) is required. Sections 1 and 2 are taught in the first half of the semester and Sections 3 and 4 are taught in the second half of the semester. Section sign-up is required by the instructor in Keck 108 during preregistration week.

course.subject: UNIV
course.title: RESPONSIBLE CONDUCT OF RESEARC
course.description: Responsible conduct of research (RCR) is defined as the practice of scientific investigation with integrity. It involves the awareness and application of established professional norms and ethical principles in the performance of all activities related to scientific research. (Formerly BIOC/BIOE 594)
course.instructor: Farach-Carson, Mary C.; Kalovidouris, Anastasia A.

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: MECHANICAL TESTING LAB MODULE
course.description: Students design and conduct a series of tests to elucidate the mechanical and material properties of animal tissue using the Instron. Section sign-up is required by the instructor in Keck 108 during the preregistration week. BIOE 372 may be taken concurrently with BIOE 444.

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: ADVNCED INSTRMENTN LAB MODULE
course.description: Students design and build a biomedical instrumentation device. Sign up is required in Keck 108 during preregistration week.

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: BIOENGINEERING DESIGN I
course.description: Senior Bioengineering students will design devices in biotechnology or biomedicine. This project-based course covers systematic design processes, engineering economics, FDA requirements, safety, engineering ethics, design failures, research design, intellectual property rights, environmental impact, business planning and marketing. Students will be expected to compile documentation and present orally progress of their teams. BIOE 451 and 452 must be taken the same academic year.

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: COMP MOLECULAR BIOENG/BIOPHYS
course.description: This is a course designed for students in computationally-oriented biomedical and bioengineering majors to introduce the principles and methods used for the simulations and modeling of macromolecules of biological interest. Protein conformation and dynamics are emphasized. Empirical energy function and molecular dynamics calculations are described. Specific biological problems are discussed to illustrate the methodology. Classic examples such as the cooperative mechanism of hemoglobin and more frontier topics such as the motional properties of molecular motors and ion channels as well as results derived from the current literature are covered.

course.subject: BIOC
course.title: IND RES FOR BIOC UNDERGRADS
course.description: Independent research in Rice BCB faculty laboratories (sections 3 and above) or other Texas Medical Center laboratories (sections 1 & 2). Students spend at least 3 hours per week in the laboratory for each semester hour of credit. If taken for 3 or more hours, counts as one required 300+ level lab course (not BIOC 311). Requires a proposal abstract, weekly reports, and a research paper (fall semester) or a proposal abstract, weekly reports, and a poster presentation (spring semester). Students wishing to perform their research in an off-campus lab must submit a completed application to the BIOC 310 instructor at least 2 weeks prior to the start of classes and may not register for fewer than 3 credit hours.

course.subject: BIOE
course.title: GRADUATE SEMINAR
course.level-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):Graduate.

course.subject: CEVE
course.title: FUNDAMENTAL OF CIVIL & ENVIR E
course.description: This introduction will cover the essential topics and quantitative techniques in civil and environmental engineering. General engineering, engineering math, fluid mechanics, hydrology, statistics, and mass balance techniques will be presented followed by applications.

course.subject: CEVE
course.title: ENGINEERING MECHANICS
course.description: The study of equilibrium of static systems, the dynamics of a particle and particle systems, and rigid-body dynamics. Required for mechanical engineering and materials science and engineering majors.

course.subject: CEVE
course.title: REINFORCED CONCRETE DESIGN
course.description: Instruction in tests of materials and reinforced concrete members.

course.subject: CEVE
course.title: CONCRETE LABORATORY
course.description: Instruction in tests of materials and reinforced concrete members.

course.subject: CEVE
course.title: PRINCIPLES OF SOIL MECHANICS
course.description: Index and classification properties of soil including soil classification systems; clay minerals and soil structure; compaction theory; engineering behavior and properties of soils including permeability, compressibility and strength; design considerations. Required for B.S.C.E.

course.subject: CEVE
course.title: SPECIAL TOPICS
course.description: Study of selected topics including individual investigations special lectures, and seminars. Offered upon mutual agreement of faculty and student.

course.subject: CEVE
course.title: ENGINEERING PROJECT DEV & MGMT
course.description: Life cycle approach to project development and management, success factors, project planning, and economic analysis contracting, project communications, network scheduling techniques, pricing and cost control, risk management, organizational structures, ethics, linear programming, global context, and project financing and contract risk analysis. Case studies.

course.subject: CEVE
course.title: MCEE SPECIAL STUDY
course.description: Independent investigation of a specific topic or problem in environmental engineering under the direction of a selected faculty member. Preparation of a formal report and oral presentation of results are required.

course.subject: CEVE
course.title: ADV TOPICS: WATER CHEMISTRY
course.description: Formal lecture and assigned reading in topics such as redox kinetics and thermodynamics, absorption and desorption, and the associated mathematics. An advanced topics course.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: INTRODUCTION TO PSYCHOLOGY
course.description: Survey of topics, problems, and approaches in contemporary psychology. Includes the biological basis of behavior, sensation, perception, attention, learning and memory, thinking, language, abnormal behavior and therapies, personality and individual differences. Required for psychology majors.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: INTRODUCTION TO PSYCHOLOGY
course.description: Survey of topics, problems, and approaches in contemporary psychology. Includes the biological basis of behavior, sensation, perception, attention, learning and memory, thinking, language, abnormal behavior and therapies, personality and individual differences. Required for psychology majors.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: INTRO TO SOCIAL PSYCHOLOGY
course.description: Overview of topics in social psychology. Includes conformity and social influence, attitude formation and change, aggression, altruism, relationships, liking and loving, prejudice and stereotyping, as well as applications to other disciplines (e.g. law, marketing, the workplace, etc.). Required for psychology majors.

course.subject: LING
course.title: LANGUAGE, THOUGHT, AND MIND
course.description: Study of language as a cognitive system. Linguistic data as evidence for the cognitive structures and processes that enable people to learn and use language; how linguistic structure influences concept formation and patterns of thinking. Without Permission of Instructor, must have Graduate Standing.
course.class-restrictions: Must be in one of the following Classification(s):Graduate.
course.level-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):Graduate.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: STATISTICAL METHODS-PSYCHOLOGY
course.description: Introduction to quantitative and computer methods applicable to the analysis of experimental and correlational data. Required for psychology majors. Psychology and Cognitive Science Majors only or Permission of Instructor(s). This course must be taken concurrently with PSYC 338.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Cognitive Sciences,Psychology.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: RESEARCH METHODS
course.description: A continuation of PSYC 339, with emphasis on individual student experiments and the writing of research reports. Required for psychology majors. Psychology and Cognitive Science Majors only or Permission of Instructor(s).
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Cognitive Sciences,Psychology.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: ADV SEM IN CLINICAL PSYCHOLOGY
course.description: Topics will vary. Repeatable for credit with Permission of Department.

course.subject: ESCI
course.title: SEM:GLOBAL SEISMOLOGY
course.description: Seminar topics may vary.

course.subject: HART
course.title: ART, ARCHITECTURE AND NATURE
course.description: This seminar considers theories and narratives of nature in the crafting of modern and contemporary art and architecture in the Americas. Artists and architects will include Maria Fernanda Cardoso, Rogelio Salmona (Colombia); Ana Mendieta, Ricardo Porro (Cuba); Ana Maria Tavaraes, Lina Bo Bardi (Brazil); Mark Dion and Buckminster Fuller (USA).

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: SUPERVISED RESEARCH
course.description: Supervised empirical research. Research paper required. Sponsorship by faculty member required.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Cognitive Sciences,Psychology.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: SUPERVISED RESEARCH
course.description: Supervised empirical research. Research paper required. Sponsorship by faculty member required.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Cognitive Sciences,Psychology.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: SUPERVISED RESEARCH
course.description: Supervised empirical research. Research paper required. Sponsorship by faculty member required.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Cognitive Sciences,Psychology.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: SUPERVISED RESEARCH
course.description: Supervised empirical research. Research paper required. Sponsorship by faculty member required.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Cognitive Sciences,Psychology.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: SUPERVISED RESEARCH
course.description: Supervised empirical research. Research paper required. Sponsorship by faculty member required.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Cognitive Sciences,Psychology.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: HONORS THESIS
course.description: Sponsorship by faculty member required. Students must apply for the Honors Program.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Psychology.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: ADVANCED PSYC STATISTICS I
course.description: Introduction to inferential statistics, with emphasis on analysis of variance. Students who do not meet registrations requirements as Graduate and Psychology Majors must receive instructor permission to register.
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Psychology.
course.class-restrictions: Must be in one of the following Classification(s):Graduate.
course.level-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Level(s):Graduate.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: COGNITIVE RESEARCH SEMINAR
course.description: A weekly student-staff seminar on current and recent research about mental phenomena.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: I/O PSYCHOLOGY RESEARCH SEM
course.description: A weekly student-staff seminar on various industrial/organizational psychology topics.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: TEACHING IN PSYCHOLOGY
course.description: Assistance in the teaching of undergraduate and occasionally graduate courses in psychology.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: FIRST-YEAR PROJECT
course.description: Individual research project undertaken in the first year of the graduate program.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: SECOND-YEAR PROJECT
course.description: Individual research project undertaken during the second year of the graduate program.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: PSYCHOLINGUISTICS SEMINAR
course.description: Weekly seminar to discuss recent research in psycholinguistics.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: THESIS RESEARCH
course.description: Research for the master's thesis.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: DISSERTATION RESEARCH
course.description: Research for the doctoral dissertation.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: RESEARCH METHODS
course.description: A continuation of PSYC 339, with emphasis on individual student experiments and the writing of research reports. Required for psychology majors. Psychology and Cognitive Science Majors only or Permission of Instructor(s).
course.major-restrictions: Must be enrolled in one of the following Major(s): Cognitive Sciences,Psychology.

course.subject: PSYC
course.title: DEVELOPMENTAL PSYCHOLOGY
course.description: Study of behavioral changes with age in both human and nonhuman species. Block II course.

course.subject: HEAL
course.title: NUTRITION
course.description: Concepts underlying the science of nutrition: food composition, calories and needs for energy, special nutrients, and nutritional deficiencies.

course.subject: HEAL
course.title: PRIN PUBLIC&COMMHEALTH
course.description: Principles of Public & Community Health examines aspects of the community that relate to health including health issues within community subgroups; identification and analysis of community health programs; organizational patterns and functions of voluntary and governmental health agencies and coordination of community health programs.

course.subject: HEAL
course.title: INTERNSHIP IN HEALTH SCIENCES
course.description: Internship experience for upper-level health sciences majors only.

course.subject: HEAL
course.title: EPIDEMIOLOGY
course.description: Study of communicable, noncommunicable, and behavioral diseases with emphasis on the disease process and basic epidemiologic methods.

course.subject: HEAL
course.title: PLANNING/EVALUATION PROGRAMS
course.description: Planning & Evaluation of Health Promotion provides the student with the technical skills for planning and evaluation of health promotion, health education, and disease prevention programs including collection and analysis of both qualitative and quantitative data.
course.class-restrictions: Must be in one of the following Classification(s):Junior,Senior.

course.subject: HEAL
course.title: DISPARITIES IN HEALTH IN AMER
course.description: Topics vary from semester to semester.

course.subject: HEAL
course.title: TEACH PRACTICUM HEALTH SCIENCE
course.description: Advanced teaching experience for upper level students who have demonstrated particular aptitude and interest in one area of kinesiology. Students will assist in conducting a course in which they have previously excelled. The student will learn techniques in course management, instruction, and evaluation.

course.subject: KINE
course.title: HUMAN ANATOMY
course.description: Introduction to human anatomy including concepts of function.

course.subject: KINE
course.title: HUMAN PHYSIOLOGY
course.description: This course will address the fundamental principles of human physiology at the cell, tissue, organ, organ system, and organism levels. Emphasis will be placed on mechanisms of function and homeostasis as achieved through the coordinated function of homeostatic control systems.

course.subject: KINE
course.title: SPORTS MEDICINE INTERNSHIP
course.description: Internship experience for senior students in sports medicine track.

course.subject: KINE
course.title: INDEPENDENT STUDY
course.class-restrictions: Must be in one of the following Classification(s):Junior,Senior.

course.subject: KINE
course.title: TEACHING PRACTICUM
course.description: Advanced teaching experience for upper level students who have demonstrated particular aptitude and interest in one area of kinesiology. Students will assist in conducting a course in which they have previously excelled. The student will learn techniques in course management, instruction, and evaluation.
